newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambian reporter denies contempt in electoral case.
newsitem.headline: Zambian reporter denies contempt in electoral case.

text.p: The Zambian supreme court on Monday charged a reporter on an independent daily with contempt in a case in which four opposition parties are challenging the outcome of the country's general elections last year.

Masausto Phiri, editor of special projects on The Post, appeared before the court to answer charges resulting from a report in which he alleged that seven Supreme Court judges had been bribed by the state to rule in favour of the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD).
In his report Phiri alleged that the government would give the judges a total of 14 billion kwacha ($10.6 million) to dismiss election petitions.
Four opposition parties are challenging the legitimacy of the elections, which they claim was rigged by the MMD by manipulating the voters register.
They are also challenging President Frederick Chiluba's credentials, and claim that he lied about his nationality and parentage in filing his electoral nomination papers.
Seven opposition parties boycotted the elections that were won in landslide by Chiluba last November.
Phiri denied on Monday that he had deliberately libelled the judges.
"What I wrote was not intended to demean or ridicule this court," he said.
The court is scheduled to rule on his case on Tuesday.
Chiluba could face up to seven years imprisonment if the court rules against him. $1 = 1,320 kwacha.
